title: 'Risky' investment: top fundie wary of buy now, pay later providers
text:
The threat of regulation looms large, with shares in Afterpay coming under pressure over the past week amid concerns about the Reserve Bank of Australia's review of rules that prevent retailers from imposing a surcharge on customer using BNPL services.

Afterpay shares are down 20 per cent from their October 15 peak.

"You never know when that regulation will hit or regulations will change or tighten, or a competitor will petition for them to be tightened behind the scenes," Mr Kothari said.

I think neo banks as a category is going to be a global phenomenon. — Beeneet Kothari

He was also concerned about the BNPL sector's willingness to take on credit risk.

"They would say we take very little credit risk, it 's very small ticket sizes, the loans periods aren't measured in years but months, or in the case of Afterpay in weeks, so the risk is minimal or manageable. But nonetheless, it's risk."

Tekne is also an investor in Facebook and Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba.

Mr Kothari said Alibaba was an "unbelievably powerful" business – with a market share in China of 70 per cent compared with Amazon's market share of 40 per cent – but it was operating in a "difficult economy" as, in his view, China was in recession.

His pick of PagSeguro bested the choice of New Oriental Education & Technology Group, which rallied 81 per cent, by Tribeca Investment Partners lead portfolio manager Jun Bei Liu.

The third place went to APS Asset Management chief investment officer Kok Hoi Wong, who picked Venustech, a network security provider in China that gained 56 per cent.

Mr Kothari remained upbeat about the prospects for PagSeguro, which offers a digital payments system for Brazil's micro-merchants, or small businesses composed of one or two people.

He said the development of PagBank, a virtual bank, was "creating a better story over the next 10 years than we've seen over the last few years" given it would open up banking services to the unbanked and underbanked.

"Globally this underbanked or unbanked population is substantially larger than people think it is," he added. "I think neo banks as a category is going to be a global phenomenon."

Ian Gibson, director of Attunga Capital, delivered the best investment portfolio return – composed of stocks recommended at the conference – among last year's conference attendees.

His portfolio, which included PagSeguro, gained 90.6 per cent.

The Sohn Hearts & Minds Investment Leaders Conference will be held on Friday, November 22.
description: Tekne Capital's Beeneet Kothari, who scored a 97 per cent gain with his top pick at last year's Sohn conference, warns about the regulatory and credit risk for the sector.
